title: China's wealthiest becoming poorer but tech billionaires on the rise
text:
"Twenty years ago, we did not have one dollar billionaire, yet now the average wealth of China’s Top 1800 individuals is a staggering US$1.4 billion ($2.1 billion). Wealth is concentrating into the hands of those who are able to adapt to the digital economy.”

Manufacturing and real estate made up just 40 per cent of the latest list, highlighting the shift in China's economy where technology companies are the fastest rises.

Newly-minted billionaires from companies specialising in artificial intelligence, facial recognition technology, robotics, drones and a coffee delivery service dominated the list.

“The speed of wealth creation in China is quite phenomenal,” Mr Hoogewerf said.

Tencent's Pony Ma rose one place to second with a $US37 billion fortune Bloomberg

Chinese-Australian businessman Chau Chak Wing, a well-know political donor, was worth 22 billion yuan ($4.6 billion) and ranked 153 on the list. His wealth increased by 2 per cent compared with last year. Mr Chau is also known as Zhou Zerong.

Huang Xiangmo, who was named in an Australian corruption inquiry this week, was worth 5 billion yuan. His fortune fell 38 per cent during the year and he fell 345 places to 828th on the list.

The list measures the wealth of people worth more than 2 billion yuan ($417 million). The number of people on the list fell by 266 in 2019, which was less than the 456 who dropped off last year. It was the first time in the report's 21-year history that China's wealthiest people become poorer for two years in a row.

There were still 192 additions to the list, including Beijing-based Li Yongxin, 43, who founded education technology giant Offcn, and Silicon Valley-based Eric Yuan Zheng, 49, of online meeting platform Zoom.

Mr Ma, who told The Australian Financial Review earlier this year, he was stepping down to focus on charity work and the education sector, was still China's richest man.

Pony Ma, 48, of Chinese digital giant Tencent rose one place to second with a $US37 billion fortune, up 8 per cent on last year. He kicked property developer Xu Jiayin out of the top two in the process.

Husband and wife team Sun Piaoyang, 61, and Zhong Huijuan, 58, doubled their wealth to US$25 billion, shooting them to fifth spot, after the Hong Kong listing of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder drug maker Hansoh. Eight per cent of the rich list is now made up of entrepreneurs from the pharmaceutical industry.

Colin Huang Zheng, 39, of ecommerce giant Pinduoduo became the first self-made entrepreneur born in the 80s to enter the Top 10, after his wealth grew US$5.7 billion to take him to US$19 billion and seventh spot.

Hurun said 156 individuals under 40 made the list this year. One of the world's most successful and youngest start-up founders is 24-year-old Colin Huang, who is worth $US20 billion after just four years.

China's food industry also produced a number of new billionaires, with pig farmer Qin Yinglin, 54, and his wife Qian Ying, 53, of Muyuan tripling their wealth to US$14 billion. Much of this came from the sale of 5.8 million pigs in a market where a devastating outbreak of swine flu pork has driven up prices.

‘Hotpot King’ Zhang Yong, 48, and his wife Shu Ping, 49, of Haidilao, doubled their wealth to $US17 billion.

Advertisement

China now has 62 billionaires measured in US dollars and 32 of those have more than $US10 billion.

The wealth of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, 75, grew 24 per cent to $US3 billion. He rose 36 places to be ranked 162 in the list of China's wealthiest individuals.

The number of people in the list fell by 4 per cent to 1819. It was the first time numbers dwindled since the 2008 global financial crisis. Still, the numbers were impressive, with 19 individuals worth 100 billion yuan or more, seven more than a year ago.

China's richest woman Elizabeth Yang, of property developer Country Garden which has extensive interests in Australia, was worth US$25 billion, up 17 per cent.

China did not have any billionaires 20 years ago.
description: The fortunes of China's richest citizens has shrunk for two years straight for the first time in 20 years, according to the country's premier rich list.
